posts.cooked:
We reset our REV through bore encoder that we got here to zero when our elevator is at the bottom. When we move the elevator and bring it back to the reset position the encoder value is off a significent value without us chaning the code or the encoder. How do we fix this.

Thanks.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Can you share the design of the elevator mechanism? Pictures? CAD? Is it a COTS model?

Specifically, I’m curious what the encoder is actually measuring (motor output shaft or something else), are there belts/chain involved, etc

The encoder is measuring its rotation. Here is our elevator, it is the thrifty bot one. Here is the shaft the encoder is on. image 510×837 83.1 KB

image 510×837 83.1 KB

image 510×837 83.1 KB

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: The throughbore encoder is practically useless there because it can only measure through one rotation. Relying on the neo internal encoder should be perfectly accurate. If you’re worried about zeroing you could add in a limit switch or distance sensor that zeroes the encoders when they get hit, but you most likely won’t need that since the elevator will most likely always start all the way down.

We know that the encoder only measures through one rotation. We have it in code for compensation of the reset.

The encoder on the Neo, I believe, is not absolute. We want it to be absolute so we do not have to rely on the same staring position every singly time. This is because of the builders randomlly powering off the robot with the elevator in random positions.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked:
Your code compensation is not going to save that rotation count during a power cycle so it still won’t be able to track the position after powering off.

TheANT:

so we do not have to rely on the same staring position every singly time

What’s wrong with starting at the same position every single time? The fact that it’s an elevator means it’s pretty easy to have a consistent point to start at. I’d recommend having something in code that resets the encoders on initialization and then I’d just make sure the elevator is all the way down before enabling the robot, which isn’t that hard especially because gravity is already going to push it down for you.

If you are dead set on having the absolute encoder I’d place the encoder on a separate shaft that is driven through a larger gear ratio so that it can measure the absolute position throughout the entire stroke length of the elevator since the code compensation is not going to save between different boots of the robot.

TheANT:

When we move the elevator and bring it back to the reset position the encoder value is off a significent value without us chaning the code or the encoder

How significant is the discrepancy between the initial reading and the final reading?

Edit: You could also use something like a laserCAN to measure the distance of the elevator travel, I’m unsure of how accurate it is but it would be able to give you a reading regardless of the position of the elevator.

The Absolute encoder does not have a reset method. Here are the docs. We will test the Neo built in encoder with the reset. Thank you for the idea for the second shaft with a larger gear ratio, however this does not change the encoder changing the 0 value.

We will reset the zero value of this encoder on the revclient and then immediatly after, before unplugging, it will move to about 0.07-0.01 without us moving the elevaor.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked:
TheANT:

The Absolute encoder does not have a reset method

Any time I mentioned resetting i was referring to the relative encoders in the motors.

What unit is that .07-.01? Because that seems like an acceptable amount of error to me.
The .07 to .01 is of a full rotation of the shaft. This is not acceptable since for normal setpoints we need an accuracy of 0.001. With a higher error we miss placing the coral on the reef.

posts.name: ERIC ZACHERL
posts.cooked: The Neo encoder does not have the resolution you need, but the relative encoder of the through bore encoder does.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: Assuming you’re using the 22T sprockets on the elevator that have a pitch diameter of 1.76”, you’re saying that you need to control the position of your elevator to within 0.00176” to not miss coral. I can guarantee that this is probably 10x smaller than the amount of general, normal slop in your system.
